There is no stack ranking (officially), so you won’t find backstabbers in your team too often. - Free Avis premium  membership which saves you a lot money on rental cars if you like traveling.
178.cons: - Career progression path might not be clear if you are stuck in an unimportant team with a manager who is not respected by the leadership. - There aren’t a lot of free perks. Food is not free. Snacks are limited. - Top down decision making with little to no focus on the voice of lower level engineers. - Culture of secrecy which makes it difficult to know about or contribute to technologies other teams are working on. - Extremely stressful life with really bad WLB and too many meetings if you are a mid level manager of an important team. Also, WLB is not great for people who take more responsibility and are higher up on the career ladder. - Internal team switches are extremely difficult and is generally not encouraged.

My boss is constantly asking me if I know about X or Y other team, what exactly they are working on, how we can best collaborate with them, or what their timelines are. If my boss doesn't know, how should I know?I have a rough overall picture, but I'm missing exact details about what other teams are doing. I've got 50+ top secret disclosures in the company and still I don't know what our closest collaborators are doing besides the tiny trickle of information they give us. This leads to a really toxic culture where managers are able to lie through their teeth at one another about how great their teams are and what they're working on. Because nobody actually knows anything there's no way to verify any claims. This goes vertically as well. Managers tend to lie to upper management about any problems or lack of velocity on things, until eight months go by and it turns into a huge problem. If the company was more honest and transparent with itself these issues wouldn't arise. It's really absurd, and an awful way to run an organization.  It can feel like you're working on an assembly line just focusing on your small part of the problem, without any exposure to the greater picture. This is extremely demoralizing. 1798.desc: "Great company with a culture that takes getting used to"
1798.pros: One thing I’ve learned from talking to people within Apple is your experience will greatly vary, depending on your organization. I’m a software engineer in the Core OS organization within SWE, so my review only applies to that.People outside Apple like to poke fun when senior leadership publicly says they’re trying to be customer-centric and do the right thing while making decisions that go in to products. After being here, I truly believe that is the case! Tim and Craig have proven to be very thoughtful, honest and effective leadersWe work on some tough technical problems and some really innovative technology.At the end of the day, as an individual contributor I am enabled to put my head down and do my best work. Apple can be demanding, expect to receive emails and pings on nights and weekends. You have to learn to set boundaries and stick to them. If you enjoy your work, like I do, it’s very easy to accidentally put too many hours in
1798.cons: As with lots of tech companies, there are many different personalities to deal with and some can make your job miserable. It sounds like being in middle management is extremely political and there are management movements / re-orgs pretty often.Apple culture can be difficult to navigate for some. There’s very little documentation (this is improving), and the company is entirely built on making relationships and hallway conversations. This can make working in remote offices difficult, from what I’ve heard. Introverts beware!
